content.description: Sit/crouch start the corner to the right of the tree with a high right hand and a bad left hand undercling. It is on the far right of the main face of the boulder and to the right of the start jug for Unknown, V6-7.
content.location: This is to the right of the start jug for Unknown V6-7, just right of the tree.

content.description: Start on a block jug on the right side of the trailside face. Follow pinches and crimps directly up and left to a slopey topout.
Do a fun sit start with matched hands, move right.... The rest is up to you. It's all there.
content.location: Hike the ledge hill trail until you reach two planks over water. After the planks, continue straight and up a hill about 1/4 mile. Look for a semi-visible trail on the right... walk 100 feet into the woods.

content.description:
Just to left of the main face of the Ravenswood Boulder, there is a little chip with a clean face and good if sharp aretes. 

  It is not a bad warm-up.

Sit start on big holds ~5 feet right of the arete, pull off of the ground to the seam, and traverse through the seam to the arete. From here, climb up the same line as Ravenswood Arete.

 This removes the crux moves of Ravenswood Arete but adds an equally challenging traverse on small hands with good feet.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spotter.
content.location: Start in the middle of the tooth/sail shaped boulder, ~5 feet right of the clean arete, in the lower seam with your right hand on a good jug and left on a good sidepull jug.

content.description:
Start by double underclinging the okayish holds on the left side of the face. From there, make strenuous moves up. The sit is likely in the double digit range.

 P.S. Just gonna call this line The Raven as to not have two unknown routes on the same boulder. If you know the name, let me know, and I'll change it.
content.location: It is on Ravenswood Boulder's main face.

content.description: Stand start with your hands in the slot. Make a big move to get the pink knob up and right. The pink knob is a protruding sloper. Balance out onto the slab and work your way up slopers to an easy top-out. The sit start adds length and bumps up the grade a bit.
content.location: To the right of the Ravenswood Arete.

content.description:
Climb the left arete and face of the obvious tooth. This involves a few tenuous and balancy slab/arete moves to a thank God crimp and easy topout. 

  It is full value V3, a little reminiscent of the Pipefitter in Lynn Woods. This is pretty classic at the grade and the sort of climb that might feel easier to oldschool rock climbers than modern boulderers.
content.protection: Pads.  Though not a true highball, the climb is thin and tall enough that it's easy to get a little sketched making the final moves.
content.location: Climb the obvious, cool, tall tooth on backside of Ravenswood Boulder.

content.description: Slide into the crack, two good hands to start. Go up and to the left.
content.protection: One pad will work with a good spot. Bring two if you have them.
content.location: Hike the ledge hill trail until you reach two planks over water, after the planks take immediate left. Hike uphill 1/8 mile. This  climb is on the back left conner.

content.description: Use the crystal pocket to gain the top.
content.location: It is right of Pink Knob.

content.description: This problem starts on two small sidepulls and moves up the overhanging face.
content.location: This is on the left-ish side of the obvious, overhanging face.

content.description: Sit start on tiny edges. It is hard.
This is a trailside boulder cluster with multiple climbs on all boulders.
